awd_titl_txt: Does the Bi-modality of UV-Optical Colors of Normal Type Ia Supernovae change the Accelerating Universe?
awd_abstract_narration:
By combining ground-based optical and near-infrared data of type Ia supernovae with UV data from NASA's Swift satellite, the research team will check the intrinsic brightness of nearby supernovae after accounting for a newly discovered sub-grouping of type Ia supernovae.  This information will be used to verify the distances to faraway galaxies and thus the amount of acceleration of the expansion of the Universe.  This will test the amount of dark energy inferred by that acceleration.  New observations of supernovae will be distributed to the public via a Twitter feed, and the PI will produce teaching modules for middle school and high school that include exciting concepts from this research.

The key to this project is to revisit the methods employed to determine the line-of-sight dust extinction to each supernova and the absolute magnitude of each supernova, this time with an emphasis on near-UV versus optical region bi-modality.  Techniques that avoid using colors to estimate extinction are emphasized as the fundamental finding is a color difference between the two groups.  These findings will then contribute to a better theoretical understanding of supernova explosion physics.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was initiated to determine whether larger, more recent datasets support the claim of bi-modality seen in the NUV-optical colors of type Ia supernovae. We have found that the bi-modality is seen in both the Swift UVOT dataset of nearby supernovae and in larger dataset of high-redshift spectra, where rest-frame UV emission is seen in the optical. The furthr goal of quantifying the potential affect of the accelerating universe has not yet been realized, but work continues. The sample if type Ia supernovae with Cepheid distances was just increased from 19 to 42, but the data is not quite publicly available. A sample of type Ia supernovae with Surface Brightness Fluctuation distances stands at 40, and we attempting to increase that sample to 74. When the sample is increased, we will then be able to present a more quantified estimate of the impact of this bi-modality on the amount fo dark energy.

While obtaining the SBF distances to type Ia supernovae in early host galaxies, we were able to derive estimates of the Hubble constant, first by combining our distances with other SBF distances to early-type galaxies, and second by combining the HST SN SBF distances with the PANTHEON+ SN Ia sample. In both cases, we arrived at Hubble constants that agree with the Hubble constant that is estimated from Cepheid variables. This in turn supports the reality of the existence of tension in the Hubble constant between local estimates and that derived from modelling Planck measurements.
